    Docstrings
    Indexing.Indexing
    Indexing.ViewArray — Type.
    ViewArray(parent, indices)

    Create an array out which is a lazy view of parent. The indices of out match the indices of indices, and the values of indices are used to index parent. Unlike SubArray, the parent type could be any indexable container (for instance, we can create an AbstractArray view of the values stored in an AbstractDict).

    See also ViewDict, view.

    Examples

    julia> d = Dict(:a => 11, :b => 12, :c => 13)
Dict{Symbol,Int64} with 3 entries:
  :a => 11
  :b => 12
  :c => 13

julia> ViewArray(d, [:a, :c])
2-element ViewArray{Int64,1,Dict{Symbol,Int64},Array{Symbol,1}}:
 11
 13
    Indexing.ViewDict — Type.
    ViewDict(parent, indices)

    Create an array out which is a lazy view of parent. The indices of out match the indices of indices, and the values of indices are used to index parent. The parent must be an indexable type - for instance, an array or dictionary.

    See also ViewArray, view.

    Examples

    julia> d = Dict(:a => "Alice", :b => "Bob", :c => "Charlie")
Dict{Symbol,String} with 3 entries:
  :a => "Alice"
  :b => "Bob"
  :c => "Charlie"

julia> ViewDict(d, Dict(:aa => :a, :cc => :c))
ViewDict{Symbol,String,Dict{Symbol,String},Dict{Symbol,Symbol}} with 2 entries:
  :aa => "Alice"
  :cc => "Charlie"

julia> v = [11, 12, 13]
3-element Array{Int64,1}:
 11
 12
 13

julia> ViewDict(v, Dict(:a =>1 , :c => 3))
ViewDict{Symbol,Int64,Array{Int64,1},Dict{Symbol,Int64}} with 2 entries:
  :a => 11
  :c => 13
    Indexing.ViewMatrix
    Indexing.ViewVector
    Indexing._valtype
    Indexing.eval
    Indexing.getindices — Function.

    getindices(container, indices)

    Return an indexable container with indices keys(indices) and values container[i] for i ∈ values(indices). This generalizes scalar getindex(container, index) for multiple indices, for dictionaries, tuples, named tuples, etc.

    Examples

    julia> d = Dict(:a => "Alice", :b => "Bob", :c => "Charlie")
Dict{Symbol,String} with 3 entries:
  :a => "Alice"
  :b => "Bob"
  :c => "Charlie"

julia> getindices(d, [:a, :c])
2-element Array{String,1}:
 "Alice"  
 "Charlie"

julia> getindices(d, (:a, :c))
("Alice", "Charlie")

julia> getindices(d, Dict("Wife" => :a, "Husband" => :c))
Dict{String,String} with 2 entries:
  "Wife"    => "Alice"
  "Husband" => "Charlie"
    Indexing.include
    Indexing.setindices! — Function.

    setindices!(container, value, indices)

    Store the given value at all the indices in values(indices) of container. This generalizes scalar setindex! for dictionaries, etc.
